title.narrative: DECP COVID-19 support to ZFE Zambia in 2020
Yangon Port Development

description.narrative: Based on the congestion/limitations of the old city port and the existing Thilawa port and taken into account the growing transport needs to cater for domestic purposes and trade to West China, it is expected that the city ports and the actual Yangon river navigation capacity will reach its limits by 2027-2030 (depending on COVID-19 recovery). The Yangon Region Government (YRG) therefore intends to develop new port facilities towards the sea on the West Bank of the Yangon River. These new facilities are designated as a location to which the existing Yangon city ports are to be relocated (strategic objective), but will also provide necessary capacity and cost reduction on the short-term (as inner ports will be relocated gradually). By shifting the inner ports, the vessel turnaround time will be reduced as the port would be closer to the sea and the dredging expenses spending on inner shallow areas will be saved too. The map below provides an overview of the port locations in Yangon, indicating the two current port locations (City Port Area and Thilawa Port) and the intended relocation of the City Port Area (New West Bank Port).

title.narrative: MHPSS Specialist Lebanon UNICEF

description.narrative: On 4th of August 2020, two explosions hit the city of Beirut, which killed more than 200 people and injured over 4000 people. Lebanon had already been suffering from political instability, economic collapse and a surge in COVID-19 cases. These multi-faceted disasters have a devastating and profound impact on the lives and wellbeing of the population and there is therefore an urgent need for reinforced capacity and resources to enable coordinated multi-sectoral MHPSS response to the varying and complex mental health and psychosocial needs of children, adolescents and families.

title.narrative: MHPSS Consultant Peru WHO

description.narrative: The main task of the MHPSS Consultant in Peru for WHO will be to work with technical UN programmes, PAHO Country Offices and Ministers of Health in prioritized countries in the region, to achieve the best attainable health status for the populations that are affected by COVID-19. The following countries have been mapped as priority for this project: Peru, Haïti, Honduras, Mexico, Nicaragua, Guatemala, Bolivia and Ecuador.

title.narrative: MHPSS Expert Pakistan WHO

description.narrative: The main task of the MHPSS Consultant in Pakistan for WHO is to support the Technical Working Group on MHPSS and specifically with the coordination with ministries, INGOs and NGOs. The consultant will have the overall responsibility for coordinating operations to ensure the timely delivery, effective and efficient implementation of the activities, to achieve the best attainable mental health and psychosocial well-being status for the populations that are affected by COVID-19

title.narrative: MHPSS Officer COVID-19 Interagency TWGs in the African Region

description.narrative: The main task of the MHPSS Officer COVID-19 Interagency TWGs in the African Region will be to provide technical support to francophone countries in Africa to strengthen the coordination of the MHPSS response and supporting the interagency MHPSS Technical Working Groups.

title.narrative: MHPSS specialist COVID emergency Haiti (WHO/PAHO)

description.narrative: As part of the WHO/PAHO Regional project to support countries to strengthen and scale up their MHPSS response capacity, the MHPSS Capacity Building Expert for Haiti will support the two Mental Health coordinators nominated by the Ministry of Health of Haiti to establish a MHPSS coordination mechanism.This project has the following objectives:Objective 1: Strengthen national capacities to coordinate and provide quality MHPSS to communities affected by the COVID-19 pandemicObjective 2: Develop and adapt communication materials related to MHPSSObjective 3: Strengthen the capacity of health professionals, frontline workers, health managers and decision makers to deliver effective MHPSS responses to the COVID-19 pandemic within and beyond the health systemPAHO will seek partnerships on both operational and technical levels with national and international non-governmental organizations, WHO/PAHO collaborating centers, academia and the Red Cross in order to enhance the Project’s impact on populations.

title.narrative: MHPSS Technical Working Group Coordinator Azerbaijan

description.narrative: Mental Health & Psycho-Social Support (MHPSS) has been identified as a priority need for the population of Nagorno-Karabakh.The leaders of Armenia, Azerbaijan and Russia signed a trilateral statement on a cessation of hostilities. This coupled with the spike in COVID-19 infections and deaths, has rendered many amongst affected population vulnerable to mental health and psychosocial distress.There is a need to have a coordinated approach on MHPSS activities in the country with focus on technical aspects including mapping of partners, capacity building, monitoring and evaluation and capacity building for long term institution of MHPSS services in regular services.To ensure responsibility, accountability and productivity of all MHPSS actors, it was agreed that a technical forum for MHPSS actions is necessary to bringing together the MHPSS actors functioning under the established and agreed Working Group. To facilitate this, the establishment of a MHPSS Technical Group has been proposed, to convene government authorities and member agencies working in Azerbaijan, summarize basic principles of good programming for MHPSS and build consensus among different actors in the field, providing a coherent framework to organizations implementing MHPSS activities in their different sectors. The main tasks of the MHPSS Technical Working Group Coordinator in Baku, Azerbaijan will be to:• Establish the MHPSS Technical Group as a forum for sharing of information and activities of national and international entities providing MHPSS services.• Coordinate the MHPSS Technical Group, support the activities of the MHPSS actors, work closely with ministries at national and provincial levels, academia, NGOs, professional organizations and Donor Community• Contribute to the design of and deliver capacity building actions such as training of trainers, specialized training and awareness raising initiatives (orientation seminars, mini-trainings, briefings, project reviews) for MHPSS Technical Group members and for the Government of Azerbaijan.• Support the planning, development and monitoring of the implementation, and capacity building activities at national/subnational level to respond to the mental health and psychosocial needs of frontline responders and essential workers.The MHPSS TG will use the Inter-Agency Standing Committee (IASC) Guidelines for Mental Health and Psychosocial Support in Emergencies and other MHPSS related documents developed by WHO and other agencies as key policy documents for programming and interventions addressing all levels of the MHPSS needs.

title.narrative: Towards a new port development strategy for Indonesia

description.narrative: The Indonesian Ministry of Transport (MoT) and Coordinating Ministry for Maritime Affairs (Menko Maritim) are in an immediate need for support to overcome the challenges they face in the port sector. Indonesian counterparts of the Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management need to rethink various aspects of port development strategies in the wake of the Covid-19 crisis. The organization of a series of webinars, followed by the jointly development strategy document, would greatly support the Indonesian challenges

title.narrative: Safe Trade Emergency Program Mozambique

description.narrative: Safe Trade Emergency Program for Mozambique (STEPMOZ) mitigates the short-term COVID-19 crisis by making trade safer at two key border points, between Mozambique and Malawi, along the Beira Corridor. This responds to demand from the Government of Mozambique and private sector partners to keep the road borders and corridors open.

title.narrative: Support to financial monitoring system, Pakistan

description.narrative: The Financial Action Task Force (FATF) is an intergovernmental organization to combat money laundering and the financing of terrorism. The objectives of FATF are to set standards and promote effective implementation of legal, regulatory and operational measures to combat money laundering and the financing of terrorism, to protect the integrity of the international financial system.Pakistan is still on the grey-list of the FATF also after the latest assessment in October 2020. a new assessment will take place to judge whether the country should be blacklisted. This situation harms the business climate of the country and has a negative impact on the financial crisis Pakistan is currently in. Therefore, this project aims to support the FMU (directly) and the Ministry of Commerce of Pakistan (indirectly) and therewith the financial sector via knowledge exchange with the Dutch Financial Intelligence Unit (FIU-NL), in order to comply with the criteria set by the FATF and be able to move to the white list. FIU-NL has valuable expertise that can assist FMU Pakistan in improving its way of working and thereby supporting Pakistan in reforming its financial system and implementing FATF criteria and recommendations. Their knowledge will be shared via remote assistance to FMU and a study visit of FMU and TAMLIT to the FIU-NL in the Netherlands, if the COVID situation allows.

title.narrative: ILO Decent work textile VN MY

description.narrative: The ILO project, lasting two to three years (2021-2023), aims to support the Governments of Viet Nam and Myanmar in skills forecasting and skills development. It should prevent the textiles and clothing industries in Asia to revert to business as usual after the COVID-19 crisis. The society must build back better and invest in more resilient, inclusive and sustainable sectors and societies. In the textiles and clothing industries, which were already undergoing a rapid and profound digital and robotics transformation, skills development and forecasting are key to helping employers and workers navigate an uncertain future and to advancing decent and sustainable work.This funding concerns an ILO project with a total project budget of 650,000 US Dollar, with contribution of:• RVO: 400,000 Euro (480,000 US Dollar);• ILO/Japan Fund for Building Social Safety Nets in Asia and the Pacific: 100,000 US Dollar, and • National governments: 70,000 US Dollar in kind.

title.narrative: Online Poultry Seminar Democratic Republic Congo

description.narrative: The study ‘Increasing self-sufficiency in poultry meat and egg production in Kinshasa’ was carried out by WUR in 2018 and because of the political situation in DRC and COVID not much follow up could be given in 2019 and 2020. In Q1 of 2021 an online event on the study will be organized with local stakeholders as well as Dutch participants.The goal is a wider dissemination of the results and conclusions of the study, creating a platform for stakeholders of the poultry industry in the DRC to discuss the possibilities to further develop the sector, identifying opportunities for the private sector as well as recommendations for the public sector in order to support the development of the poultry sector and by connecting Congolese actors to the expertise of the Dutch poultry sector.

title.narrative: Rural connectivity for the young: support to Hosts for Peace project in Nariño and Putumayo, Colombia

description.narrative: The implementation of the Peace Agreement with FARC in Colombia is supported by the Netherlands through political and financial commitment via the European Union Trust Fund for Peace (EUTF). The multiannual plan of the Embassy supports the implementation of the Comprehensive Rural Reform to strengthen local economies (training, agricultural production chains and access to markets) of communities affected in the internal conflict in Colombia. The project complements the ongoing Host for Peace project that is being implemented by ICCO cooperation with support of the EUTF to offer vocational training and support business initiatives in the Putumayo and Nariño regions; two of the most affected regions of the internal conflict in Colombia.. The project enables rural connectivity and ensures the continuity and finalization of the training in entrepreneurship (gastronomy and tourism) of 262 rural young Afro-Colombian women through an inclusive business model during the COVID-19 pandemic crisis that doesn’t allow presential training due to the lock down measures. The project leads to the further development of micro and small businesses by increasing the affordable offer of internet in remote areas of these regions.

title.narrative: Chamber of Commerce Training of Trainers

description.narrative: The Federation of Palestinian Chambers of Commerce, Industry and Agriculture (FPCCIA) based in Ramallah is piloting the founding of an ‘ICU unit’ to help MSMEs which are negatively affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. The ICU unit will provide MSMEs with technical assistance. For the pilot, 20 MSMEs have been selected and the major areas of improvement have been identified in a study. Through RVO’s support, 18 trainers (one from each Palestinian Chamber of Commerce, which are members of FPCCIA) will be trained on four topics of improvement, so that they can support the MSMEs as an ICU unit (training of trainers). The expert giving the training of trainers will also coach the selected 20 MSMEs in the pilot phase.

title.narrative: Scoping study healthcare Philippines

description.narrative: In 2019 the President of the Philippines signed the Universal Healthcare Act into law, kicking off what is supposed to be an ambitious overhaul of the Philippine healthcare system. In 2020 the COVID-19 pandemic hit the Philippines, exposing some of the shortcomings of the Philippine healthcare system in software, hardware and orgware. The starting point for this project is the current situation: how does the health care sector look like, who are the stakeholders, and what venues are there for potential cooperation between the Netherlands and the Philippines in the healthcare sector?This project will result in an analytical report on the sector, a road map with proposed follow-up actions for the embassy and two webinars for Dutch and Philippines stakeholders on the results of the study. This study should serve as the starting point for further development of local private healthcare parties with the ultimate goal of strengthening the Philippines healthcare sector.

title.narrative: Consumer behaviour & food safety poultry in Myanmar

description.narrative: This project is about the increase and the acceptance and food safety awareness and improve the reputation of professionally slaughtered and processed poultry meat among Myanmar consumers.In 2020, the first modern poultry slaughterhouse of Myanmar, with a capacity of 1,000 birds per hour, has been opened at the premises of Wai Yang Aung in Yangon. Allowing to meet the highest international standards in terms of hygiene, food safety, working conditions and animal welfare. However, Myanmar consumers are hard to convince to buy cooled or frozen poultry meat slaughtered at professional slaughterhouses instead of whole birds to be slaughtered at home or wet markets. Thus, the arrival of modern slaughterhouses does not automatically imply that consumers will shift towards buying these poultry products.Therefore, the poultry meat processors, retail chains and public stakeholders will be advised on the most promising marketing campaign approach, including an implementation roadmap, to boost the reputation of and the demand for hygienically slaughtered, processed, stored and transported poultry meat.The current COVID-19 pandemic and growing global attention for food safety offer a good momentum to initiate a shift in consumer behaviour.

title.narrative: Number of people directly reached - Dutch
Nexus Project Peru: NL-PE expert support for implementation of Santa Eulalia scoping mission water, energy and food security (WEF)

description.narrative: Peru, together with the Netherlands, are part of the UN High Level Panel on Water (HLWP) and both are convening countries of the Global Commission on Adaptation. The Water Energy and Food Security (WEF) nexus approach fit in the overall national and international policy ambitions of both countries to ensure efficient use of natural resources and solve climate change challenges.The project complements and facilitates the implementation of the scoping mission of the project “WEF Nexus in the Santa Eulalia river basin in Lima, Peru. This mission is implemented by Deltares (water), TNO (energy) and Wageningen University (food) in a digital format due to the travel restrictions imposed by the COVID 19 pandemic. The purpose of the scoping mission is to better understand the current situation in the Santa Eulalia river basin, to consult with the key stakeholders and to identify the current and future problems related to the water, agriculture and energy sectors. This to be able to formulate more precisely the objectives, scope and deliverables of the PSD WEF nexus study for Santa Eulalia river basin planned for 2021. The WEF project will help reduce and/or avoid potential trade-offs over the use of increasingly limited water (surface water and groundwater), energy, land and food resources and will promote a better management of these resources at the local, regional and national level.This project provides local and Dutch technical and operational support to the Netherlands embassy in Lima for a successful implementation of the digital scoping missions.

title.narrative: DRA Babile Oromia and Moyale Somali Region Desert Locust Response

description.narrative:
Emergency Desert Locust  Response in Babile Woreda (Oromia) and Moyale woreda (Somali  Region). 

Key objective: people provided with resources to protect and start rebuilding livelihood assets
Specific objective: addressing the most urgent needs of 27.395 desert locust affected people by providing MPC, emergency livelihood assistance and WASH support related to COVID-19.

Target group: A total of 27.395 individual beneficiaries (M:4931, W:6027, G:9040, B:7397) will be targeted.

Main activities:
- Distribution of specialized crop and grass seeds and farming tools, restocking of livestock for female-headed households and capacity building on DL control at the community level,

- Provision of MPC (Multi-Purpose Cash),

- Intervention to prevent the spread of COVID-19, such as distribution of Hygiene Kits, hygiene promotion and Installation/reparation of boreholes.
Expenditure 2020
Income to be recived from ETH 20143
NLD to ETH Recved fro ETH20143

title.narrative: Nigeria Joint Response 2020

description.narrative: DRA funded NJR project with partners Tearfund, SCI, ICCO, and TdH. ZOA implements CASH component in Monguno LGA (in collaboration with ICCO partner JDPH), and WASH in Mafa LGA (in collaboration with SCI). In Mafa there is a small CASH component in collaboration with SCI.
1st Instalment received - NGA2001 (NJR)
Contract NGA2001 (NJR-COVID 19)
Contract NGA2001 (NJR2020)
Expenditure 2020

title.narrative: ACC-R1 Participation

description.narrative: ACCR1 - ACC-R1 Participation

title.narrative: ACC-I1 - Number of crisis-affected people who are also involved in the design, implementation, monitoring and/or evaluation of the programme

description.narrative: Recruit community level staff from affected communities, conduct feedback meetings and post distribution monitoring among beneficiaries

comment.narrative: This comprises recruited hygiene promoters, community nutrition mobilizers, community committees, community leaders and participants of community engagement and feedback meetings. Hygiene promoters received training on conducting hygiene promotion and safety measures, especially during COVID. They all received training on PSEA, accountability to affected population and the ZOA's complaints and response mechanisms. WASHCOM members received training in repair and minor maintenance of hand pumps.

title.narrative: CHS-R1 Unconditional and unrestricted cash

description.narrative: CHSR1 - CHS-R1 Unconditional and unrestricted cash

title.narrative: CHS-I1 - Number of people benefitting from unconditional and unrestricted cash

description.narrative: 8 months of multipurpose cash for 1630 individuals in Monguno LGA and 5 months of multipurpose cash for 1000 individuals in Mafa LGA

comment.narrative:
A total of 6,045 individuals received cash: 3,228 under NJR2019 top-up and 2,817 under the regular NJR2020 MPC.
Beneficiaries reached under NJR2019 top-up (Monguno): 3,228 individuals, 51.2% females were reached. Of this number, 2,359 received a monthly per capital transfer value of NGN6,940 over the period of six months. 2,171 individuals collected 6 tranches; 159 individuals collected 5 tranches; 6 individuals collected 4 tranches and 33 individuals collected 1 tranche totaling 2,359 individuals or 102.56% of the original project target of 2,300 individuals to receive 6 rounds of cash.
Due to underspend on vendors commission and other budget lines, ZOA provided one round of emergency multipurpose cash to 869 fire victims within the project location. The per capital transfer amount was NGN3,595. 2,359 individuals reached under the original target + 869 reached with one-time emergency cash gives a total of 3,228 individuals reached.
Beneficiaries reached under NJR2020 (Mafa/Monguno): 2,817 individuals received multipurpose cash in Monguno and Mafa under the regular NJR project. Of this number, Monguno accounts for 1,778 while Mafa accounts for 1,039 individuals referred by SCI for cash support. Cash collection rate in Mafa was 99.9% while that of Monguno was 99.7%. Due to delays by EFCC to issue cash clearance, the transfer in Monguno was short by two months, 6 instead of 8 rounds.

title.narrative: FSC-COV-R3 Prevention and response to COVID-19 pandemic related to Food Security & Livelihoods

description.narrative: COVR3 - COV-FSC-R3 Prevention and response to COVID-19 pandemic related to Food Security & Livelihoods

title.narrative: FSC-COV-I3 - Number of people receiving COVID-19 related assistance (FS&L)

description.narrative: Cash provided to individuals with protection concerns for food

comment.narrative:
Four protection organizations referred 295 households with protection concerns for cash support. These households contained 1,016 individuals. 98.5% of cash electronically transferred to these households was redeemed. The remaining 1.5% accounts for households that left the project areas before end of project as well as those excluded for varying reasons. For example, a household was referred twice by two protection organizations.
The protection organizations that ZOA worked with are: IRC and PUI (two international organizations) and GISCOR and HARAF (two national organizations)

title.narrative: WSH-R1 Hygiene promotion

description.narrative: WSHR1 - WSH-R1 Hygiene promotion

title.narrative: WSH-I1 - Number of people having regular access to soap to meet hygienic needs

description.narrative: 1,200 households benefit from both hygiene promotion and soap for laundry and bathing

comment.narrative: 1,196 households/families or 8262 individuals (137.7% of target) have benefitted from the distribution of soaps to meet up with daily basic hygiene needs. The soaps include 3 pieces of laundry soaps (200g) and 13 pieces of bathing soaps (250g). The number of beneficiaries reported represents the actual household membership reached.

title.narrative: WSH-R2 Excreta Disposal

description.narrative: WSHR2 - WSH-R2 Excreta Disposal

title.narrative: WSH-I2 - Number of people having access to dignified, safe, clean and functional excreta disposal facilities

description.narrative: Construction and rehabilitation of 95 stances of latrines and 50 units of bathing shelters

comment.narrative: Additional 20 stances were constructed to the initially constructed 95 stances across 3 of the 5 communities (Zannari, Simari and Mala Kyariri); making a total of 115 stances of latrines. This was because there were still needs and the budget allowed ZOA to fill the gaps by constructing additional stances of latrines and bathing shelters. Additionally, 18 stances of bathing shelters were constructed across 3 of the 5 communities where the needs persisted. These additional latrines and bathing shelters were constructed as stand-alone (a block of one) and were all gender segregated and marked. ZOA worked with the communities in selecting the locations for latrines and bathing shelters and in identifying areas with the most needs.

title.narrative: WSH-R3 Drainage

description.narrative: WSHR3 - WSH-R3 Drainage

title.narrative: WSH-I3 - Number of people living in settlements with a functional drainage network

description.narrative: Cleaning of drainages within residential areas of targeted beneficiaries

comment.narrative: The drainage cleaning equipment were distributed across all 5 communities. Equipment include; Diggers (50), Wheel barrows (25), Shovels (50), Hand gloves (50), Gum boots (50), Metallic rakes (10) and Water pump set (1). Materials purchased were recommended by respective communities during feedback meetings. All equipment were left in the custody of the communities' respective leader's households and intending users collected these equipment, use them and refund them when they are done so other groups could also have access to the tools. This was also a suggestion from the community members during one of the feedback meetings as the equipment was not enough for distribution in smaller clusters. All 8262 individuals who received soap reside in these locations.

title.narrative: WSH-R4 Water Supply

description.narrative: WSHR4 - WSH-R4 Water Supply

title.narrative: WSH-I4 - Number of people having access to sufficient and safe water for domestic use

description.narrative: Construction/rehabilitation of 2 solar boreholes to provide water access to affected population

comment.narrative: The 2 solar powered boreholes drilled in June were fully equipped and commissioned in July 2020 and one additional solar powered borehole was rehabilitated in Simari community bringing the total number of solar boreholes to 3 to benefit 9000 individuals. The borehole is equipped with 20 cubic meters overhead water tank with reticulation to 1 fetching point which has 10 tap heads. Due to existing water gaps and on the request of the community, ZOA repaired/rehabilitated 7 dysfunctional handpumps in Mala Kyariri and Simari communities to benefit 3,500 individuals

title.narrative: WSH-R6 Hygiene promotion (Awareness)

description.narrative: WSHR6 - WSH-R6 Hygiene promotion (Awareness)

title.narrative: WSH-I6 - Number of people reached with hygiene promotion/awareness raising activities

description.narrative: Hygiene promoters conduct hygiene promotion activities in project communities

comment.narrative: 9 additional hygiene promoters (5 males and 4 females) were recruited locally to add to the existing 16 hygiene promoters; making a total of 25 hygiene promoters (10 males and 15 females). This was done to increase the reach of hygiene promotion and COVID - 19 awareness messages. Beneficiaries were reached through door to door visits only as per recommended by the WaSH sector due to the COVID - 19. All hygiene promoters were equipped with nose masks and hand sanitizers and maintained social distance during sensitization sessions. The increase in household membership benefiting from hygiene promotion was due to the existence of households with larger membership as well as the willingness of other households to participate in hygiene promotion sessions.

title.narrative: Syria Joint Response 2020 (Lead Agency): Dutch Relief Alliance - NGOs Joint Humanitarian Response to the Syria Crisis

description.narrative: Overall goal SJR2020: Improved wellbeing of conflict-affected people inside Syria, especially the most vulnerable. Interventions will be done in the areas of Food Security and Livelihoods, Health, Individual household shelter, Protection and Multi-Purpose Cash.

SJR2020 will focus on Syria, targeting the most vulnerable households. Within Syria the choice has been made to concentrate on Aleppo and Rural Damascus. It is anticipated that SJR2020 will reach around 111.533 beneficiaries

title.narrative: Syria Joint Response 2020

description.narrative:
The project will rehabilitate domestic shelter for vulnerable families in Aleppo, including household adaptations for people living with mobility impairment. This activity is carried out by ZOAs partner Medair.

In Aleppo and Rural Damascus, ZOA will work with GOPA-DERD to identify most vulnerable families for vocational training in subjects likely to provide a future income for the households. Participants will also receive lifeskills training, and cash for attendance while undergoing the training. 

The activities are closely coordinated with other SJR partners, to facilitate referrals of beneficiaries, and joint learning.

Covid-19: The Covid-19 project aims to provide essential water, sanitation and personal hygiene goods and services for preparedness and prevention of COVID-19 to 9, 000 vulnerable individuals in Nashabiyeh (Duma, Rural Damascus). The main project activities are: -distribution of hygiene kits -installation of household water tanks -communication of critical risk information. CHS: The overall expected result by the end of 2020 is that ZOA Syria Response and its local partners operate more in line with the ZOA standard ‘Way of Working’, thereby strengthening adherence also to the Core Humanitarian Standards. Funding is within the SJR fund, a budget of 22,000 EUR has been allocated to accountability/CHS. Project Objectives are: 1. Strengthened accountability for affected populations 2. ZOA Management team is equipped to lead and manage staff 3. ZOA programmes are conflict sensitive 4. ZOA has more and better equipped local partners

title.narrative: Increase member involvement through the association activities to increase revenue and membership base

description.narrative: 2019 PlanPlanned activities include My.Coop Aggregation training Youth workshop FM coaching development of extension strategy2020 PlanExchange Business visit to PDFA Advanced Record Keeping (Might be skipped due to Covid Financial management training Governance training and Youth council masterclass and development of extension strategy for 2020

The mian objcetive of CDFA is to diversify their income sources and increasing their capital base and reducing on donor dependency. The association also realizes the need to increase its membership base and involving youths and women as it has an impact on their revenue. However the association sees the need to provide more member services to its members as a way of proving its relevance need for members to affiliate. BHAG 2021: A financially self-sustaining organisation providing quality services to 4 750 members towards a profitable agribusiness by focusing on improved crop production promoting mixed-farming and improved marketing. Objectives: Increasing membership to 4750 and becoming a financially self sustaining organisation

The project will focus on increasing revenue for the association through member involvement and provision of extension services. It will also tackle the issue of youth and gender inclusiveness to help youth participation in the development of the district through the association. They will be coaching in financial management to help the organisation put internal controls and assess the business's potentil to grow.

title.narrative: Down to Zero: Building Back Better in times of Covid-19

description.narrative: The programme will build and expand on the Alliance’s collective achievements to date, scaling up the 2016-2020 Down to Zero (DtZ) programme and being complementary to the 2020-2021 Voice for Change (VfC) programme. This will allow the Alliance and its partners to effectively address SEC in the rapidly evolving context during and after the Covid-19 pandemic.

participating-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs the Netherlands

title.narrative: Joining Forces for Africa (JOFA)

description.narrative: This action has been designed to respond rapidly to the global COVID-19 pandemic emergency. It seeks to address the most marginalised vulnerable population in the 5 target African countries: Ethiopia, Kenya, Mali, Senegal and Uganda.Children are the hidden victims, facing threats to their wellbeing and protection as a result of the increased risks of violence and abuse. Infection prevention control measures that national governments have taken to limit the spread of the disease have a direct impact on the lives of children and their increased exposure to violence. The proposed action seeks to address the immediate protection needs of children

title.narrative: BBB Bangladesh : Building Back Better in times of Covid-19 Bangladesh

description.narrative: The Covid-19 pandemic has exacerbated the already complex web of vulnerabilities of children who are victims of, or at risk of SEC  and poses unprecedented threats to their protection. The projectś goal is to make sure children and youth are better protected when at risk or victim of sexual exploitation, during and in the aftermath of the Covid-19 pandemic. This will be achieved through the projects 5 outcomes. This project is under the programme DtZ Building Back Better in times of Covid-19 that will build on the 2016-2020 DtZ and complement the 2020-2021 Voice for Change.

title.narrative: Strengthening the health system to maintain access to quality care in the context of COVID-19

description.narrative: To support the Ministry of Health to face the COVID-19 pandemic, this project aims to intervene in 260 health structures in the 6 districts of Boucle du Mouhoun, to strengthen the prevention and management of COVID-19, access of the most vulnerable populations to primary health care and access to better hygiene and sanitation. Objectives: 1- Capacity building of health structures 2- Improving access to water and hygiene 3-Support CSPS through HR, medical and logistical equipment 4- Strengthen the capacities of health workers in psychological first aid, treatment of GBV and PSS to health workers. Contract start date is 01-08-2020, but ECHO has agreed that we can start on 01-09-2020.
Expenditure 2020

title.narrative: BF Burkina Faso Joint Response 2019

description.narrative: Since early 2019, non-state armed groups have consolidated their presence in especially the Northern part of Burkina Faso. There has been a sharp increase in violence which has unfolded a dramatic humanitarian crisis. Currently, Tdh responds through an Acute Joint Response in the Titao district, with service provision including in primary health care, natal care, GBV treatment, child protection, PSS. Project funded by the Dutch MFA, with Plan as lead organisation. Project includes a COVID-19 Top Up.

comment.narrative: The former DCC proposed refurbishment of former police canteen to be used as a CPU. This proposal has been disputed by the current DCC. He has categorically stated that a CPU should only be established at the police station. This will ease deployment and sustainability. Consultations are still underway with the County Commissioner and OCPD Teso North on commitment and provision of alternative site for the CPU. In regards to the Isolation center, the medical officer has proposed a facelift of the maternity wing as the padeatric wing ( Isolation is brand new) and might require minimal actions.;

title.narrative: # of advocacy activities conducted aimed at influencing the increase of government budget allocation for children needs

description.narrative: # of advocacy activities conducted aimed at influencing the increase of government budget allocation for children needs

comment.narrative:
3 advocacy activities were conducted. The Busia County CSOs analysed the CIPD 2018-2021, County Budget Review and Outlook Paper (CBROP)2020/MTEF 2021/2022-2023/2024 & CFSP for FY 2021 - 2022 , Engaged with the MCA and County Authority, CSOs subsequently submission of a memorandum to the County assembly for petitioning for increased budget allocation for children's needs.
Here is the link to the County website https://busiacounty.go.ke/main/index.php/downloads/category/6-county-budget-documents Under expenditure due to planned consultant fee for engagement of cec that was not utilized hence savings. The savings will be used to host a breakfast meeting between the County Children Assembly members and contribution towards development of Children Policy;

The activity was delayed because the development of initial evidence brief and advocacy messages was dependent on the results of the Needs Assessment and Baseline report, The activity will be conducted between February and March, 2021 with reference to the Needs Assessment and baseline report.;

comment.narrative:
201 ( (94M & 107F) community members participated in community dialogues. The structured community dialogues were facilitated by different experts : Health, Gender and Children departments under the leadership of the Deputy County Commissioners & Senior Chiefs (NGAO) The aim of the dialogue was to sensitise the community members on VAC - identification, prevention and response; on the available referral pathways. In addition, the impact of Covid-19 (SGBV, child exploitation, child labour
Under expenditure was due to the fact that radio talk show were not undertaken hence no cost incurred The savings will be used to support countywide radio talk-show with a special focus on SGBV and teenage pregnancies;

Approximately 125,000 communities/public reached through 3 local radio stations: Nyota FM, Bulala FM & Emuria FM in partnership with CRS - MWENDO implementing partners. Discussions were conducted in Kiswahili and local dialect. 84 participants reached during dissemination of the EVAC 2020-2024 strategic plan conducted at County and at the sub counties level. 155 members participated in community dialogues held in two locations ( Nangoma and Kocholia,
Under expenditure as less was spent on community dilogues and IEC materials are yet to be procure. Ban;
The activity is planned for Q4 2021 hence no expenses reported.;

comment.narrative: 16 Days of Gender activism was planned for, however, the department of children services, mandated to mobilise children for the planned activity had an overlapping activity, organised from the national office. The budget spend relates to child webinars as Smart phones budget for were not procured.;

The initial budget allocated for children's airtime was reduced by half. This allowed us to support additional 8 children from Mombasa and Marsabit Counties. Furthermore, Mtoto News used the same platform to facilitate participation of additional 7 children from Kitui, Nairobi, Machakos, Kwale and Narok Counties. This activity was implemented during the reporting period . The expenses will reflect in the next Quarter.;

title.narrative: Improving reporting and response of CSEC cases during COVID-19 through the national Child Helpline -116

description.narrative: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID‑19) pandemic is exacting a huge toll on children, families, communities, and societies across the world, thus TdH-NL will support the costs of engaging (5) counselors to increase the human resource capacity of the Helpline 116
Expenditure 2020

title.narrative: Children Immediately safeguarded (provided counselling, rescue and referrals)

description.narrative: Children Immediately safeguarded (provided counselling, rescue and referrals)

title.narrative: # of boys immediately safeguarded

description.narrative: # of boys immediately safeguarded

comment.narrative: A total of 14,024 boys were safeguarded. Out of the total; 5318 boys went through counselling for Child abuse, reproductive health, relationships, Self-esteem and Identity issues. 92of there cases were of child abuse. 8706 were cases of information inquiry on 116 services and child rights issues. 1483 cases were referred to the Children office, Chief’s office, Kenya Police and Court. Childline’s case management team is following up these cases with the different service providers and the clients to ensure delivery of quality service. The target was not reached, the Call Centre experienced internet downtime which affected the number of calls received. There was an over expenditure on budget because costs for girls immediately safeguarded was reported under this activity.;

A total of 3,751 boys were safeguarded. Out of the total; 2,494 boys went through counselling issues like abuse(Physical, Neglect and Abandonment), reproductive health, et cetera. 1,257 were referred to the Children office, Chief’s office, Kenya Police, Court, and CSO's like red cross and MSF for support. Childline’s case management team is following up these cases with the different service providers and the clients to ensure delivery of quality service. No children were rescued during this period. The target was not reached because the contract with the donor was signed late. However, plans have been made to meet the target in the subsequent months. There is an under expenditure because project staff salary for the month of July was not paid due to delay in signing of the contract;

title.narrative: # of girls immediately safeguarded

description.narrative: # of girls immediately safeguarded

comment.narrative: A total of 15165 girls were safeguarded. Out of the total; 6028 went through counselling on various child protection issues like abuse (Sexual abuse, child marriage, physical abuse), relationships, reproductive health among others. 2586 were referred for other services to children offices, Kenya police, Hospitals, chief’s office for support. Childline’s case management team is following up these cases with the different service providers and the clients to ensure delivery of quality service. No children were rescued during this period. The target was not reached, Call Centre experienced internet down time which affected the number of calls received. There was an under expenditure on the activity because some cost for the activity were reported on number of boys safeguarded.;

A total of 4195 girls were safeguarded during the reporting period. Out of the total reached, 2567 girls went through counselling on various child protection issues like abuse(Sexual abuse, child marriage, physical abuse), child-parent relationship, boy-girl relationships, reproductive health among others. 1,628 were referred for other services to children offices, Kenya police, Hospitals, chief’s office and other partners for support. All the cases are being followed up by Childline’s case management team. No children were rescued during this period. The target was not reached because the contract with the donor was signed late. However, plans have been made to meet the target in the subsequent months. There is an under expenditure which was brought by delay in signing of the contract.;

title.narrative: " Community members with children vulnerable to exploitation participated in awareness raising activities - Using media (social media, radio, TV) to target parents and caregivers "

title.narrative: # of community members with children vulnerable to exploitation participated in awareness raising activities

description.narrative: # of community members with children vulnerable to exploitation participated in awareness raising activities

comment.narrative: The Covid- 19 awareness messages were shared through Childline’s social media pages i.e. Facebook and Twitter where 1371 people were reached. The target was not met because, peer educators delayed in giving feedback on the messages before they could be used. Since more children will be engaged in October 2020, they will be able to interact with the awareness messages and provide feedback. To meet the target, daily posting of the messages on social media and frequent boosting will be done. The messages will also be shared through TV and Radio stations. The funds allocated to this activity were never used because only few messages had been shared. With the frequent boosting of the social media messages and airing via mass media in the coming month the budget will be utilized.;

The Covid- 19 awareness messages were shared through Childline’s social media pages i.e. Facebook and Twitter where 60430 people were reached. In addition to this 763000 people were reached via KTN News TV and Ramogi FM. The target was overachieved because the radio stations have a big coverage hence more people were reached. There was also frequent boosting on the social media which contributed to more people being reached. There was an expenditure on this activity because the budget for the previous quarter was utilized to boost the content online.;

title.narrative: WATCH 24/7 Kenya : Working together for child online protection in Kenya

description.narrative: The need for this project is born out of experience in implementing interventions against OCSE in Kenya, which has witnessed an increase in online child sexual exploitation. The proposed intervention comes at a time when a lot of online learning is taking place due to closure of schools as a result of Covid-19.

title.narrative: Nigeria Joint Response 2020

description.narrative: Second year that Tdh responds to the Nigerian crisis within the Nigeria Joint Response, funded by the Dutch MFA, and led by Save the Children. Location: Borno State (Mafa, Dikwa and Gwoza LGA) Activities include WASH, natal education, cholera/ malaria/ measles awareness, community based management of childhood illnesses - through mobile teams, PSS, CPiE awareness and CM. Project includes a COVID-19 Top Up and Innovation scale-up funding.

title.narrative: BBB Nepal:Down to Zero - Building Back Better in times of Covid-19 (DtZ-BBB)

description.narrative: With a close collaboration with Government, law enforcement agencies and private sector actors in Nepal, this project will be able to address the issue of SEC in a holistic manner incorporating the feedback and experiences of all stakeholders. The first hand information from the field will be applied by informing and addressing a wide range of stakeholders from several levels of government and LEA including the communities, CBOs, students and survivors. All of them coming together to address the issues of human trafficking and SEC within a time of urgent and ever changing response is needed.

participating-org.narrative: WYSHER (Women Youth Empowerment in Social Service and Human Rights)

title.narrative: Philippines: DtZ Building Back Better in times of Covid-19 in Cebu Province

description.narrative: The Building Back Better of Down-to-Zero Project for 2021 is focused on continuing existing services for the protection and prevention of Online Sexual Exploitation of Children (OSEC) and Sexual Exploitation of Children in Travel and Tourism (SECTT) in Cebu Province with the integration of recovery and rehabilitation amidst the COVID-19 pandemic situation. This project aims that children and youth are better protected when at risk or victim of sexual exploitation, during and in the aftermath of the Covid-19 pandemic.

title.narrative: Syria Joint Response 2020

description.narrative: For the sixth year, Tdh is part of the Syria Joint Response, funded by the Dutch MFA, and led by ZOA. Tdh is mostly providing assistance to people with disabilities in Jaramana, Qattana, Daf El shok, Eastern Ghota (Rural Damascus) and Jeble (Aleppo). Activities: Food vouchers, MHPSS and physical rehab, fisiotherapy, or rehab. Project includes a COVID-19 Top Up.

description.narrative: Key strategy is to create a sustained response that especially takes into account the vulnerability that the Covid-19 emergency has created so children’s voice is amplified so that the full range of stakeholders are aware, mobilised and supported to promote protection systems. Due to the content of Covid-19 emergency especially increasing the vulnerability to OCSE, then the community level awareness and reporting systems will especially focus on OCSE feeding into reporting and the strengthening of CPS to enable sustained resilience.

Renforcement des capacités des établissements d'enseignement en santé et droits sexuels et reproductifs (SDSR) pour l'inclusion des jeunes au Bénin

description.narrative:
Le projet vise le renforcement des capacités d’institutions d'EFTP/ES et d’organisations partenaires au Bénin à consolider la formation SDSR axée sur les jeunes. Il s'inscrit dans le contexte des défis importants auxquels ceux-ci sont confrontés en matière de SDSR, notamment les grossesses précoces, les avortements à risques, les IST, combiné au déficit de compétences et d’accès aux travailleurs du secteur sanitaire et social. Avec une approche genre sensible aux besoins des jeunes, le projet visera la révision et l'intégration des programmes de formation SDSR, le renforcement des capacités d'enseignement et la mise en place d’une plateforme basée sur la recherche pour le dialogue et l'engagement politique. Les activités du projet favoriseront l'apprentissage croisé entre les organisations participantes afin d'autonomiser les professionnels SDSR pour renforcer leur efficacité collective pour l’inclusion des jeunes. Ceux-ci amélioreront ainsi leurs capacités à relever leurs défis de SDSR et pourront mieux réaliser leurs objectifs éducatifs et professionnels. L'impact de la Covid-19 nécessitera aussi l’intégration de l'apprentissage à distance. À long terme, le consortium localsera un mécanisme durable pour la mise à jour continues des programmes d'études SDSR, le renforcement des capacités de formation, la recherche appliquée et l'amélioration du dialogue intergénérationnel sur SDSR et l'inclusiondes jeunes.
​
OKP-ICP-BEN-104887
The proposed project must contribute to the following long-term impact: −Better information and greater freedom of choice for young people about their sexuality

Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.
